Now about all this bitching. I will say, with all due respect, that extremezone torrents are sometimes not quite what I would consider what the label represents. However, they are always good. I never considered that some people might be on "limited bandwidth" and whatnot. However again, this is their choice. If they download an extremezone torrent, and do not find it to their liking, they do not have to upload from him again. I have unlimited, so if he has something I'm interested in, though I may not always be "100%" happy, I've never, EVER, been flat out disappointed.

At the end of the day, he is uploading quality torrents that otherwise I would not find elsewhere, or would have to wait several more days or weeks to get. So thank you very much extremezone. Your work is very much appreciated.

The movie is garbage. It's not just that I don't like the way the "central metaphor' is presented.

The movie is inept. In one scene Ray Liotta gets out of a car in a torrential downpour. It is incredibly obvious that the rain is coming down between him and the camera, as neither him, nor his clothes, become wet. Then the scene cuts to a second camera angle, and, instantly, he's as wet as a drowned rat.

Continuity much?

I know I should be concentrating on the deep underlying message of the movie, rather than its realism, but that's difficult to do when the set-up is so ridiculous:

Two idiots rip off a mafia card game; a game that's already been robbed: 

We're to believe

1.) There's no doorman/ security at the game, even though the game has already been subject to a prior heist.
2.)The twenty wise guys in attendance have no problems depositing a combined hundred thousand dollars in buy-in money in a brief case which is left unprotected and unattended in a cupboard in another room
3.)The two thieves are able to walk out of the heist, one at a time, down a hundred foot long alleyway, with no one so much as attempting a pursuit, or, say, pointing a gun down said alleyway and killing the thieves.

Scene after scene is stretched by the use of CNN and CSPAN, not because the message needs to be repeated with such frequency, but because MR. Dominik is a lazy, stoned writer who couldn't be bothered to rouse himself from his lethargy long enough to finish writing a script.

The only reason I can see for this movie's existence is that Brad Pitt enjoys getting baked with it's director. In order for Mr. Pitt to feel he is spending his recreation time with a colleague rather than a paid flunky, an employee, he leaned his considerable clout to the making of this careless mess.

Awww.... Brad bought a friend.

This movie, isn't just bad. It's incompetent.
